headline: Suit: Goldman Didn't Disclose SEC Probe
summary: A Goldman Sachs shareholder filed a lawsuit against the bank, accusing the firm of failing to disclose a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation.

headline: Luxury Autos on Show in Beijing
summary: While Beijing's auto show features hybrids and electric cars and dozens of other models aimed at China's mass market, luxury car makers from around the world have also wheeled out their latest offerings at the 200,000-square-meter exhibition area.

headline: CVC to Buy 19% Stake in Sun Hung Kai
summary: Sun Hung Kai, which controls Hong Kong brokerage and fund manager Sun Hung Kai Financial, said it agreed to sell up to a 19% stake in itself to private-equity firm CVC Capital Partners for $275.7 million.

headline: Earnings Watch
summary: Earnings Watch

headline: Weighing if Suit Should Head to Trial
summary: In class-action lawsuits, both the company being sued and the plaintiffs making the complaint have an incentive to reach a settlement before the case goes to trial, experts say, because juries are so unpredictable—sometimes awarding plaintiffs big sums and sometimes nothing.

headline: Corporate Watch
summary: Corporate Watch

headline: Daewoo Motor Sales Kept Afloat
summary: Creditors of Daewoo Motor Sales have reversed their decision to let the vehicle sales and real estate development company go bankrupt, the main creditor said.

headline: Adventures in Curry
summary: Cooking classes in Bangkok can make Thai cuisine, with its many pastes, sauces and spices, easier to master.

headline: China's Auto Show Kicks Off
summary: With a flurry of new vehicle launches, auto makers from around the world are scrambling for a share of China's surging market at the Beijing auto show.

headline: Viola Davis Returns to the Stage in "Fences"
summary: Tony winner Viola Davis talks to The Wall Street Journal about her new Broadway play "Fences," her co-star Denzel Washington, and her film work with Meryl Streep and Julia Roberts.

headline: USDA Cracks Down on Synthetic Fatty Acids in Organic Milk
summary: The Obama administration, continuing its crackdown on the organic-food industry, is moving to eliminate synthetic fatty acids widely found in organic baby formula and organic milk.

headline: Deficit Panel Faces Early Criticism
summary: A panel established by Obama to solve the country's fiscal crisis will meet Tuesday for its inaugural meeting amid accusations from both the left and right that it will fall prey to election-year politics.

headline: Perelman Joins Group for Philadelphia Dailies
summary: Ronald Perelman, the billionaire financier and chairman of cosmetics company Revlon, has joined a group of Philadelphia investors seeking to buy the city's two daily newspapers out of bankruptcy protection.

headline: Blankfein: Goldman Didn't Consistently Short Home Market
summary: Goldman Sachs' CEO will tell lawmakers Tuesday that the firm didn't consistently short the residential housing market, didn't bet against clients and lost $1.2 billion because of the mortgage crisis.

headline: GM to Bolster Work Force
summary: General Motors is set to announce plans to add or keep more than 1,000 factory jobs at five U.S. and Canadian plants.

headline: 'The Art of Victorian Photocollage'
summary: In a society known mostly for being formal and stuffy, several creative women of the Victorian era expressed their artistic side by creating whimsical and sometimes satirical works of photocollage. The Metropolitan Museum of Art explores this genre with the exhibition "Playing With Pictures: The Art of Victorian Photocollage," on view through May 9.

headline: Marc De Vos: The Trouble With Belgium
summary: The surrealism of its linguistic, economic and social problems will soon become very real.

headline: Geronzi's Arrival a Black Mark for Generali
summary: The appointment of Cesare Geronzi as chairman of the Italian insurer is a bad day for the company, and for the reputation of corporate Italy.

headline: Obama Eulogizes West Virginia Miners
summary: President Obama eulogized 29 coal miners who died in an April 5 explosion in West Virginia's Upper Big Branch mine, in a Sunday speech that avoided assigning blame for the disaster.

headline: Gold Prices Inch Up
summary: Gold futures finished nearly steady as traders balanced a stronger dollar and weaker crude oil against expectations for further investment demand in other currencies.

headline: Rate Fears Pressure Oil Prices
summary: Crude-oil futures lost ground as traders feared last week's strong economic data that pushed oil above $85 a barrel may also push the Fed closer toward eventually raising interest rates.

headline: Air China to Up Spending
summary: Air China, the world's largest airline by market capitalization, plans to increase its capital spending by 50% this year and add capacity to meet the surge in demand for air travel.

headline: High Court to Hear Videogame Case
summary: The U.S. Supreme Court agreed Monday to decide the constitutionality of a California law that seeks to ban the sale of violent videogames to minors.

headline: Amadeus Could Top Europe IPOs
summary: Amadeus is set to price its initial public offering on Tuesday, testing investors appetite for Spanish-listed travel stocks at a time when both the Spanish economy and global travel continue to slump.

headline: San Miguel to Buy Into Petron
summary: San Miguel said it will exercise an option invest in a company that holds a majority stake the Philippines' largest oil refiner.

headline: Swire Seeks up to $3.09 Billion
summary: The property arm of Swire Pacific is seeking to raise up to $3.09 billion in Hong Kong's largest initial public offering so far this year.

headline: Humana's Profit Rises
summary: Humana's earnings rose 26% on the reversal of prior reserves for medical claims and on higher premiums and enrollment at its government segment.

headline: Recovery Hopes Lift Europe; Nikkei Jumps
summary: Miners and industrial stocks gained in Europe, underscoring a belief that the global economy is recovering. Japanese exporters rose on the yen's recent weakening.

headline: Bank Stocks Fall as Senate Nears Key Vote
summary: Financial stocks fell as traders bet that proposed derivatives regulation from Senate Democrats would hurt revenue at most big banks, though many investors think there is little chance of the measure passing in such a stringent form.

headline: Green Exchange Files for Independent Status
summary: Green Exchange filed for independent exchange status, marking a step forward for the emissions-trading unit owned by CME Group.

headline: Stern Lesson
summary: JOHN FUND ON THE TRAILSEIU's new leader is said to want to reorient the union away from political action and back to old-fashioned organizing.

headline: Japanese Yields Rise; Hana Bank Prices Bond
summary: Japanese government bond yields rose as investors sold safe-haven assets on the back of higher Tokyo shares and a lower yen. A sale of two-year notes is set for Tuesday.

headline: Fifth Avenue Gem Is Back on Block
summary: One of the world's most valuable retail spots is going back on the city's commercial real-estate market, which is showing signs of getting back on its feet. A partnership led by the Carlyle Group aims to fetch between $600 million and $700 million for part of the first and second floors of 666 Fifth Ave.

headline: Alberto-Culver Profit Rises
summary: Alberto-Culver's earnings rose 7.3%, helped by sales gains for its TRESemme hair-care brand and more moderate commodity costs.

headline: China's Half-Open Door
summary: Reform momentum has stalled and the business environment is deteriorating.

headline: Cameron Supports U.K. Election System
summary: U.K. Conservative party leader David Cameron said he supports the current electoral system, but refused to pledge not to discuss changes after May 6 elections if his party doesn't have a majority.

headline: Newspapers' Circulation Slips
summary: Circulation at many U.S. newspapers continued to slip in the latest six-month period, with the average readership dropping 8.7% for 602 dailies.

headline: Hong Kong Seeks Ban on Tiger Asia Fund
summary: Hong Kong's securities regulator said it wants to ban New York-based hedge fund Tiger Asia from trading in the city.

headline: Whirlpool's Profit Soars
summary: Whirlpool's earnings more than doubled as consumer demand increased, thanks in part to government-run stimulus programs.

headline: Iran, Uganda Fail to Reach Oil Deal
summary: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad's visit to Uganda ended without a deal on Iran's proposed investment pledges to Uganda's upcoming oil sector.

headline: Central Bank Move Strengthens Ruble
summary: The Russian ruble strengthened to new highs against a basket of euros and dollars as the central bank shifted its floating trading band, allowing the currency to advance.

headline: How to Buy a Home at Auction
summary: You can pick up a deal at an auction—if you do a lot of sleuthing in advance, and can keep your emotions in check.

headline: Home Sales Jump, but Outlook Remains Cloudy
summary: Tax credits spurred a large jump in home sales, as first-time buyers took advantage of low prices and interest rates. But the longer-term outlook for the market remains clouded, with a large inventory of foreclosed homes expected to hit the market.

headline: Lorillard's Profit Surges
summary: Lorillard's profit jumped 26% as cigarette shipments increased.

headline: The New Face of Japanese Deflation
summary: Falling prices in the 1990s were a sign of restructuring. Now they're a warning that something's going wrong.

headline: A Closer Look at India's Rich Bank Stocks
summary: The worst may be over for India's banks, but stock investors convinced that the best is right around the corner may want to think twice.

headline: U.K. Freezes Iraqi Airways' Assets
summary: The U.K. High Court ordered Iraqi Airways' assets frozen globally after the carrier failed to pay Kuwait Airways $1.2 billion in compensation for stealing aircraft during the 1990 invasion of the Gulf state.

headline: Quanta Posts 22% Profit Rise
summary: Quanta Computer said its first-quarter net profit rose 22% and it expects strong growth in notebook computer shipments in the second quarter, suggesting the recovery in consumer demand for electronic products is on a firm footing.

headline: Carphone Warehouse Sees Growth
summary: U.K. mobile-phone retailer Carphone Warehouse said its fiscal-year results were ahead of expectations, and expects strong earnings growth next year.

headline: Intl Paper Raises Dividend
summary: International Paper announces a sharp increase to its quarterly dividend and a $200 million deal to acquire an Asia packaging business.

headline: Greece Confident of Bailout Package
summary: Greece's finance minister said that he expects final terms and conditions of an aid package for Greece to be ready by early May and that it will be acceptable to all his partners in the euro zone.

headline: Bridgestone Plans New India Plant
summary: Japanese tire maker Bridgestone is looking to ride one of the world's fastest-growing automobile markets by ramping up production and setting up a second factory in India.

headline: Index, TAG Unite on  Start-Ups
summary: Index Ventures has teamed up with an early-stage investment firm to jointly back entrepreneurs at their earliest stage of development.

headline: Maruti Profit More Than Doubles
summary: Maruti Suzuki, India's largest car maker by sales, posted a more than twofold rise in quarterly net profit, but lagged analysts' estimates as higher metal costs outweighed rising demand for its Swift, A-Star and Ritz small cars.

headline: Center-Right Party Wins in Hungary
summary: Viktor Orbán and the Fidesz party won Hungary's runoff general election with the widest majority in the country's postcommunist history—giving the new government sweeping powers to carry out its promises.

headline: Canon's Net Profit More Than Triples
summary: Canon's first-quarter net profit more than tripled, propelled by brisk camera sales and a strong recovery in demand for printers.

headline: Crackdown on Paraguay Militants
summary: Paraguay declared a state of emergency and approved get-tough tactics, including the suspension of some constitutional rights, in response to a Marxist group's killing of four people last week.

headline: Asia Higher on Greece, Yen
summary: Asian shares rose Monday after U.S. gains and as concern eased over Greece. A weaker yen boosted exporters in Japan.

headline: U.A.E. Minister Lowers Growth Forecast
summary: The economy minister of the United Arab Emirates lowered his 2010 economic growth forecast for the country to 2.5% from 3.2%.

headline: Fixing Greece May Leave Europe Weaker
summary: Even if a Greece bailout deal gets done, the bailers will have only applied a Band-Aid to a hemorrhage.

headline: Thais Worry About Lasting Violence
summary: Fears are growing that Thailand's political crisis could cause lasting damage to its economy and international reputation as the country edges closer to a potentially bloody showdown.

headline: Iran Taps New National Oil Head
summary: Iran's oil minister has replaced the head of the giant National Iranian Oil, as the presidential loyalist tightens control of the industry amid increased sanctions.

headline: Remembering the Dead
summary: Armenians Saturday marked the 95th anniversary of the 1915 killing of Armenians. Armenians demand Turkey recognize as genocide the killing of 1.5 million between 1915 and 1917 by the Ottoman Empire.

headline: Conoco Exits Saudi Refinery Venture
summary: ConocoPhillips dropped out of a refinery project in Saudi Arabia as the U.S. oil major cuts back in its refining and marketing business.

headline: Saab Names New CEO
summary: Swedish defense and security company Saab said it has appointed Hakan Buskhe as president and chief executive officer.

headline: United Spirits Plans Acquisitions
summary: India's United Spirits is planning acquisitions at home and overseas in a bid to ramp up production and boost exports, said the managing director of the world's second-largest liquor company by volume sales.

headline: Immigration Law Boosts Governor
summary: Arizona Gov. Jan Brewer's call to raise taxes threatened her political future; her decision to crack down on illegal immigration could save it.

headline: Liberal Democrats Strike Blow to Brown
summary: The leader of the U.K.'s smaller opposition Liberal Democrats party said he wouldn't join a government led by Gordon Brown if the governing Labour party came third in the election.

headline: Corporate Watch
summary: Corporate Watch

headline: Daewoo Motor Sales Fate Mulled
summary: Daewoo Motor Sales may be allowed to go bankrupt after failing to repay $16 million in debt, a main creditor said.

headline: India's Suffering Cities
summary: Managing the path of urbanization is essential for India to raise the living conditions of a substantial number of its citizens. Here are some snapshots of India's urban development until now.

headline: Romancing the NFL Draft
summary: Columnist Jason Gay takes his wife to the NFL Draft and, shock, discovers she's bored by it all and will only stay for the first hour.

headline: Pimco Embraces Emerging-Market Corporate Debt
summary: Pacific Investment Management, the world's biggest bond-fund manager, is increasingly investing in emerging-market corporate debt, part of a move to ramp up exposure to the fastest growing economies and assets with the highest returns.

headline: 'The Perfect Justice of Allah'
summary: The latest case of U.S.-al Qaeda links.

headline: Finance Bill Hits Impasse in Senate
summary: Republicans joined in the Senate to block Democrats' overhaul of financial regulation, opening a period of uncertainty for the bill.

headline: Yale Doctor Is Gunned Down
summary: A Yale University medical doctor was shot and killed  outside his suburban home, and police charged an ex-colleague who had claimed the victim humiliated him.

headline: Treasury Gives OK to Sell Some Citi Shares
summary: The U.S. Treasury Department approved a sale of 1.5 billion shares of Citigroup common stock in a step toward reducing its 27% stake in the Wall Street firm. The shares will be sold in smaller chunks at the prevailing market price.

headline: Noma Named Top Restaurant
summary: Copenhagen's Noma, which showcases the work of a young Danish chef whose dishes include radishes in edible dirt, edged out top "molecular" eateries to win the award for world's best restaurant.

headline: Hope Trickles Into California Farms
summary: There is new hope in California's drought-stricken farm economy, as water agencies open irrigation spigots a little more this year, allowing farmers to increase planting and hiring.

headline: Spring Boosts Home Depot, Lowe's
summary: Consumer spending appears to be giving home-improvement retailers a boost.

headline: Hertz Plans to Buy Dollar Thrifty
summary: Hertz plans to buy rival rental-car company Dollar Thrifty for about $1.2 billion, improving access to the leisure-travel market and reducing dependence on business travel.

headline: O'Grady: Ortega Tries to Join the Axis of Evil
summary: Nicaragua's president employs street violence to do an end-run around the constitution and assure his election.

headline: Clearinghouses Aren't the Answer for All Derivatives
summary: In his April 21st op-ed "Clearinghouses Are the Answer" Commodity Futures Trading Commission Chairman Gary Gensler outlined why exotic derivatives between financial institutions should be forced onto exchanges with expensive collateral requirements to reduce systemic risk.

headline: Sending Wolfson to D.C., Mayor Shoots for Peace
summary: After a testy meeting last week between a Bloomberg aide and the New York congressional delegation, deputy mayor Howard Wolfson plans to meet lawmakers to calm the waters.

headline: Only in New York: Moderate Looks Strong
summary: In some ways, one of the most surprising stories of the 2010 midterm election season is that Democratic Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand of New York is still considered a fairly safe bet for re-election.

headline: Bloomberg's Salt Assault Gets Allies
summary: Sixteen food makers and restaurant chains have agreed to cut salt as part of a push to trim Americans' salt consumption by 20% over five years, Mayor Bloomberg plans to announce Monday.

headline: A Two-Sport Threat at the Meadowlands
summary: The Giants took as their third-round pick in the NFL Draft LSU safety Chad Jones, who pitched on the Tigers' 2009 national-championship baseball team.

headline: Contrarian ETF Crowd
summary: None

headline: For Banks, Simpler Is Better
summary: How many Citigroups can a banking system bear? That is a question Congress has to consider as efforts to pass a financial-sector overhaul bill gain steam.

headline: Wait, Who's Playing QB Next Year?
summary: Over the past 10 years, only 18% of the teams that reached Bowl Championship Series bowls (16 of 88) were quarterbacked by a first-time starter.

headline: Iraq Disqualifies 52 Ballot Names
summary: An Iraqi election-review body disqualified 52 candidates from the country's March 7 parliamentary elections, including one winner.

headline: Entrepreneurs Succeed With Specialty Lenders
summary: Business owners who use specialty lenders have an edge: The loan officer knows the revenue potential, financing and cash-flow needs of that industry and can advise of any snags in the business plan.

headline: Deal May Force Trading-Desk Spinoff
summary: The tentative agreement reached by two key Democrats on a plan to crack down on trading in derivatives would potentially force banks to spin off their operations that trade the exotic financial instruments.

headline: Stifel to Acquire Thomas Weisel Partners
summary: Deal would combine a St. Louis regional brokerage and investment banking firm with a San Francisco high-tech investment bank.

headline: Icahn Wins Battles In Lions Gate War
summary: Icahn, in his fight for Lions Gate, won support from a major proxy advisory firm and gained the right to vote his shares against the film company's poison pill proposal.

headline: From Social Maven to Student
summary: Rena Sindi shares how maneuvering New York's social scene helped her navigate business school.

headline: Unions, States Clash in Race to Top
summary: Obama's signature education initiative has incited showdowns in states as unions and state officials feud over strategies to compete for $3.4 billion in federal funding.

headline: Charles River to Buy China Firm
summary: Charles River is expected to announce the acquisition of one of China's largest drug research contractors, WuXi AppTec, for $1.6 billion.

headline: BofA Near Chairman Decision
summary: Frank Bramble and Charles Holliday are the leading contenders to be named chairman of Bank of America following the shareholders meeting.

headline: Are You Ready for Your Video Chat?
summary: Video chatting, helpful as it may be for keeping in touch, can be intimidating. Katherine Boehret  goes into the basics.

headline: IPL Chairman Modi Suspended
summary: The Board of Control for Cricket in India suspended Lalit Modi, the controversial chairman and creator of the popular Indian Premier League, as it probes whether he abused his position.

headline: U.S. Firms Wary of China Protectionism
summary: A new survey from the American Chamber of Commerce in China indicated that concern is growing among U.S. businesses in the country that protectionist policies are threatening their long-term future in a key market, even while they remain optimistic about an economy that has rebounded strongly from the global recession.

headline: Fannie Offers Incentives
summary: Struggling homeowners who give up their homes before foreclosure or voluntarily transferring ownership will face a shorter waiting period before being eligible for another mortgage backed by Fannie Mae.

headline: Push for Global Bank Tax Bogs Down
summary: Canada, Australia, Japan and other nations are firmly opposed to the idea of a global bank tax to cover future financial crises. The U.S., Germany, France and the U.K. still support the idea.

headline: Modell Not Counting on LeBron's Arrival
summary: The CEO of Modell's Sporting Goods doesn't think it's likely LeBron James is coming to a New York-area team, based on Nike's merchandise plans for the fall.

headline: Senate Readies Goldman Assault
summary: Goldman had a strategy of shorting the mortgage market, making $3.7 billion from the tactic, Senate investigators said, setting up a showdown with Goldman executives testifying Tuesday.

headline: Little Reason Posted for 3M's Lag
summary: There is little reason why 3M's shares should be lagging behind the industrial sector.

headline: Consumer Mojo Lifts Profits
summary: Consumers are spending again, delivering a strong boost to first-quarter corporate sales and profits.

headline: Not All Employment Declines Are Bad
summary: William P. Suliburk (Letters, April 21) calls the decline in manufacturing employment "disconcerting" and considers the growth in teachers and health-care workers to be indicative of "misallocation in the employment of our labor force."

headline: U.S. Seizes Big Batches of Fake Goods
summary: U.S. officials said they made their biggest-ever seizures of counterfeit goods this month in two operations that netted more than $240 million in total.

headline: Car Shares Get Zoned for Garages
summary: New York City will unveil a zoning proposal that permits car-sharing services to park vehicles in garages and lots citywide, a move officials hope will dramatically expand the environmentally friendly industry's stake in the city.

headline: Christie's Opens the Ultimate Walk-In Closet in Brooklyn
summary: A Christie's International PLC subsidiary is converting a hulking century-old factory in Red Hook into a high-security storage site designed to hold millions of dollars' worth of art. It aims to open in June.

headline: Pakistan Defends Its Soccer Industry
summary: Sialkot, Pakistan, exports about 70% of the world's hand-stiched soccer balls. But the city's factories increasingly face competition from machine-made balls produced in China.

headline: Peter Wallison: Taxpayers and the Dodd Bill
summary: The FDIC could borrow vast sums to bail out failing banks and their creditors.

headline: Data, Fed Add to Treasury-Auction Pressure
summary: Treasurys face a challenging week, as investors deal with hefty debt auctions, the uncertainty of a Fed meeting and key economic data.

headline: Oil Spills Into Gulf After Disaster
summary: The oil well connected to a drilling rig that sank in the Gulf of Mexico last week after a fiery explosion is gushing crude oil, raising fears of a severe environmental hazard.

headline: Matsui's Not a Big Loss (Financially Speaking)
summary: The loss of Hideki Matsui, along with the Japanese advertisers he brought to Yankees, hasn't harmed his former team financially.

headline: Asian Carp Fix: Just Eat It
summary: One Chicago chef is helping to spearhead a campaign to eat the pesky fish out of existence, or at least making a dent in the population. Carp ceviche anyone?

headline: Bay Is All Hills and Valleys
summary: When the Mets paid $66 million for their new power-hitting outfielder, Jason Bay, they were under no illusions about one quirk of his character. He's a streaky hitter.

headline: Slayings Stir Fears in Harlem
summary: Some residents of Central Harlem fear the neighborhood could return to its crime-ridden past after a weekend murder on the same street where another slaying occurred days earlier.

headline: The Euro Can Survive a Greek Default
summary: In many ways, a messy default would actually leave the single currency in better shape.

headline: Tracking King's Killer
summary: In April 1967, James Earl Ray escaped from prison, wandered the country and then decided to assassinate Martin Luther King Jr. Hampton Sides tells Ray's story in "Hellhound on His Trail" and describes the FBI's 65-day manhunt, ending in Ray's capture in June 1968. Douglas A. Blackmon reviews.

headline: Goldman's Tourre MeetsWith Senate Investigators
summary: On Saturday, Goldman released batches of emails by Mr. Tourre to girlfriends that revealed doubts about some mortgage securities issued by the company and an occasionally dismissive attitude toward the investors buying them.

headline: Police Let Terrorist Slip Through
summary: Port Authority police were told to search would-be subway bomber Najibullah Zazi's car last September as he drove up to the George Washington Bridge -- but waved him across without finding hidden explosives.

headline: A Tribeca Rehab for $28 Million
summary: The owner of this Tribeca penthouse turned a shell, with raw exterior siding and insulation, into a five-story haven for art.

headline: U.S. Energy Policy Should Help the U.S., Not China
summary: I have been warning for six months about the danger to America's economy and national security presented by the Chinese utilizing state-owned banks to provide funding for state-owned oil companies to buy or control oil supplies ("China's $20 Billion Bolsters Chavez," page one, April 19)

headline: For the Mets, Pelfrey Makes It Rain Zeroes
summary: By pitching five innings Sunday night to squeak by the Atlanta Braves, 1-0, in a game shortened by rain, Mets' Mike Pelfrey stretched his scoreless streak to 24 innings, the best of his career.

headline: 666 Fifth Poses Test for Market
summary: The price ultimately fetched for the two floors of prime retail space at 666 Fifth Ave. will test whether the city's real-estate market has rebounded from its worst trough in decades.

headline: French Bank Teams Up for Chinese Experiment
summary: Crédit Agricole and Citic Securities reached a preliminary deal that would be a Chinese first: a foreign player joining forces with a top-tier Chinese securities firm to underwrite and trade shares in the country.

headline: Laptops Steal Netbooks' Thunder
summary: Pricier, more powerful notebook computers are sucking some of the steam from netbooks, the low-priced darlings that helped fuel sales for the PC industry in the past two years.

headline: No Rush, A-Rod, We Have All Day
summary: When Derek Jeter hits a home run, it takes him 20.19 seconds to round the bases, the second-fastest time among Yankees starters. Alex Rodriguez needs 24.94 seconds, the slowest mark on the team.

headline: Indian Party Denies Phone Tapping
summary: Home Minister P. Chidambaram denied a magazine report that officials of India's ruling alliance ordered an intelligence agency to monitor phone calls by some senior Indian political leaders.

headline: Deconstructing the 'Cathedral of Junk'
summary: The city of Austin, Texas, wants a 60-ton, two-story backyard edifice brought up to code. See if you can find some items hidden in the cathedral.

headline: Economists See Hope in Portugal
summary: Most economists say Portugal is better-positioned to fix its finances than Greece and is unlikely to slide into a debt crisis like Greece's.

headline: Technology Central to CIA Plan
summary: The CIA announced a five-year strategic plan that would invest heavily in new technologies to combat non-traditional threats like cyber attacks from overseas and gain better intelligence on rogue states.

headline: Signs Point to More Stock Gains
summary: The technical analysts who spend their time tracking the U.S. stock market's internal signals say there is enough strength and momentum in the current rally to push the market even higher.
